item.title: How air pollution is driving the rise of cardiovascular diseases - Hindustan Times
item.description:
How Air Pollution Contributes to Cardiovascular Diseases

Date: Dec 16, 2024

Source: Hindustan Times

This article discusses the serious impact of air pollution on cardiovascular health, detailing how long-term exposure leads to increased risks of heart disease, inflammation, and morbidity.

  • Air pollution is responsible for one in eight deaths globally, with 8.1 million deaths recorded in 2021.
  • It currently shortens the average life span by one year and eight months.
  • The pollutants can cause inflammation and oxidative stress in the circulatory system, raising the likelihood of cardiovascular diseases.
  • Poor air quality introduces contaminants into the bloodstream, leading to increased blood pressure and heart issues.
  • Mitigation strategies include monitoring air quality, reducing outdoor activities during high pollution days, and supporting anti-pollution policies.
“The interactions between air pollution and health outcomes are diverse and complex... ranking second after high blood pressure, dietary risks and smoking.” – Dr. Naresh Kumar Goyal

In conclusion, addressing air pollution is crucial for improving public health and reducing the incidence of cardiovascular diseases.

item.title: A Simple Kiss Turned Deadly—How An Allergic Reaction Almost Took Her Life - Times Now
item.description:
A Simple Kiss Turned Deadly—How An Allergic Reaction Almost Took Her Life

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Times Now

A 28-year-old film producer, Phoebe, shares a life-threatening allergic reaction incident that occurred when she was 18 during a trip to Paris, triggered by a kiss.

  • Phoebe experienced a severe allergic reaction after kissing a man who likely had consumed nuts.
  • Symptoms included throat swelling, rash, and panic, leading her to use her EpiPen.
  • Important information about anaphylaxis and safety measures during such allergic reactions is highlighted.
“I never imagined a kiss could trigger such a severe reaction. It’s important for people to understand that even indirect exposure can be dangerous for those with severe allergies.”

The article emphasizes the critical nature of awareness and education regarding allergies and anaphylaxis for both those with allergies and the general public.

item.title: 10 dry fruits and how much protein they contain - The Times of India
item.description:
10 Dry Fruits and How Much Protein They Contain

Publication Date: Dec 16, 2024 Source: Times of India

Protein is an essential nutrient that plays a crucial role in building muscle, strengthening bones, and promoting overall health. These dry fruits may help you with your day’s intake easily and healthily. The following quantities of protein are per 100 grams, according to the USDA.

  • Almonds - 21g: Almonds are rich in monounsaturated fats and fiber, promoting satiety and overall health.
  • Walnuts - 15g: Walnuts provide essential fatty acids beneficial for heart health.
  • Pistachios - 20g: They support muscle building with a favorable amino acid profile.
  • Cashews - 18.22g: High in protein and also packed with vitamins and minerals.
  • Peanuts - 25.80g: Classified as nuts due to their high protein content.
  • Hazelnuts - 13.33g: Can help lower bad cholesterol levels.
  • Dates - 2.5g: High in fiber and support digestive health.
  • Fox Nuts (Makhana) - 9.77g: Great for fasting diets, providing significant protein content.
  • Raisins (Kismis) - 2.5g: Known for their health benefits related to digestion.
  • Dry Figs - 2.5g: Used to address various health issues due to their nutrient content.

item.title: Winter Joint Pain: Causes, symptoms, and when to seek medical help - The Times of India
item.description:
Winter Joint Pain: Causes, symptoms, and when to seek medical help

Publication Date: N/A Source: N/A

Winter often brings about joint pain for many individuals, and understanding its causes and symptoms is essential for seeking appropriate medical help when necessary.

  • Discusses common causes of winter joint pain.
  • Highlights symptoms to watch for.
  • Provides guidance on when to seek medical assistance.
“Understanding joint pain can significantly improve one’s quality of life during the colder months.”

Recognizing the signs of winter joint pain can help individuals manage their symptoms and seek timely medical intervention to maintain their health.

item.title: India reduces malaria caseload, deaths by 69% each from 2017 and 2023, says WHO report - Asianet Newsable
item.description:
India Reduces Malaria Cases and Deaths by 69%, Says WHO Report

Publication Date: 2024-11-01

Source: World Health Organization (WHO)

India has successfully managed to control malaria, significantly reducing both the caseload and mortality rates, according to the latest World Malaria Report.

Key points from the report include:

  • 69% reduction in malaria cases from 6.4 million in 2017 to 2 million in 2023.
  • 69% decrease in malaria deaths from 11,100 to 3,500 in the same period.
  • India has exited the High-Burden-High-Impact (HBHI) group of endemic countries.
  • The South-East Asia Region reported four million malaria cases, with India contributing to half of those.
“India has made progress in reducing the malaria burden because of its multi-sectoral approach and political commitment to bring down the burden.” - Dr. Daniel Madandi

This progress highlights the effectiveness of India's malaria control strategies and its commitment to public health, potentially influencing global health policies moving forward.

item.title: How moderate coffee consumption reduces cardiovascular disease risk - News-Medical.Net
item.description:
How Moderate Coffee Consumption Reduces Cardiovascular Disease Risk

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Nutrients

A comprehensive review highlights the complex relationship between coffee consumption and cardiovascular disease, exploring potential health benefits, bioactive compounds, and the need for further research.

  • CVD is the leading cause of mortality globally, responsible for over 17 million deaths annually.
  • Healthy eating patterns can significantly improve cardiovascular health, while coffee consumption is linked to a reduced risk of mortality and CVD.
  • Moderate coffee intake (3-5 cups daily) appears to provide the most benefits; extreme amounts may be harmful.
  • Bioactive compounds in coffee, such as chlorogenic acids, diterpenes, and trigonelline, may contribute to its health benefits.
  • The effects of caffeine are debated, although moderate consumption is generally considered safe.
“Overall, the health effects of coffee are complex and depend on various factors, thus making it challenging to draw definitive conclusions about its impact on cardiovascular health.”

More research is needed to confirm the health benefits of coffee on cardiovascular disease.

item.title: Want to have sharp mind? Do this activity daily to increase intelligence for 24 hours - The Times of India
item.description:
Want to have sharp mind? Do this activity daily to increase intelligence for 24 hours

Publication Date: Not specified | Source: International Journal of Behavioral Nutrition and Physical Activity

The article discusses how engaging in moderate to vigorous exercise can enhance memory and cognitive function for up to 24 hours, based on new research findings. It explains the mechanisms behind this brain boost and offers practical suggestions for incorporating exercise into daily routines.

Key Points:

  • Exercise enhances brain blood flow, oxygen, and nutrient delivery.
  • Physical activity releases feel-good brain chemicals, improving focus and mood.
  • Exercise improves sleep quality, especially deep sleep, aiding in memory processing.
  • Benefits from exercise can last into the next day, contrary to previous beliefs.
  • Simple activities like walking, dancing, and yoga can be effective.
“Anything that gets your heart rate up—like climbing stairs or a quick jog—can make a big difference for your brain. And the benefits extend well beyond a few hours after exercising.” - Dr. Mikaela Bloomberg

The article emphasizes that regular moderate exercise is key not just for physical health, but for cognitive capabilities as well.

item.title: Winter Workouts: Avoid Excess to Reap Health Benefits, Warn Experts - The Bridge Chronicle
item.description:
Winter Workouts: Avoid Excess to Reap Health Benefits, Warn Experts

Published on: 16 Dec 2024, 1:28 pm IST

As winter motivates many to start exercising, health experts caution against over-exercising, stressing moderation to prevent physical and mental health issues.

  • Exercise enhances health but must be approached carefully.
  • Moderation is key to avoid adverse effects from overly intense workouts.
  • Experts recommend gradual increases in activity levels.
  • Specific guidelines for different forms of exercise are provided.
“Exercise should always begin at a moderate level and gradually increase,” advised Dr. Avinash Bhondwe, former president of the Indian Medical Association (IMA).

In conclusion, individuals should prioritize a balanced approach to fitness this winter, ensuring they stay within safe limits to enjoy the health benefits of exercise.

item.title: 10 common habits that promote longevity - The Times of India
item.description:
10 Common Habits That Promote Longevity

Date: Dec 16, 2024 Source: TimesOfIndia.com

Incorporating certain habits can help promote long-term health and enhance the quality of life, allowing individuals to live longer and happier lives.

  • Promote long-term health and well-being
  • Learn stress management techniques through yoga and meditation
  • Stay hydrated for overall wellness
  • Live purposefully to enhance life satisfaction
  • Practice daily gratitude for better mental health
  • Limit intake of sugar and processed foods
  • Grow a garden to promote well-being
  • Maintain strong social connections
  • Get enough sleep to support health and cognitive functions
  • Focus on consuming nutrient-rich foods
  • Keep learning to foster cognitive health
“Lifelong learning promotes a healthy brain by fostering curiosity, enhancing knowledge, and developing new skills.”

Incorporating these habits can greatly influence one's longevity and overall quality of life.

item.title: Get Party-Ready In No Time: Cosmetologist's 4-Step Skincare Hack For Glowing Skin - NDTV
item.description:
Get Party-Ready In No Time: Cosmetologist's 4-Step Skincare Hack For Glowing Skin

Publication Date: March 7, 2024 | Source: NDTV

This article shares a simple 4-step skincare routine recommended by cosmetologist Dr. Jaishree Sharad to achieve glowing skin quickly for party readiness.

  • Step 1: Dunk your face in ice for 3-5 minutes to reduce puffiness and tighten pores.
  • Step 2: Use a sheet mask with hydrating ingredients like hyaluronic acid or vitamin C for 10-15 minutes.
  • Step 3: Moisturize with a product containing hyaluronic acid to lock in hydration.
  • Step 4: Apply lightweight makeup for a glowing finish, focusing on highlights and a fresh lip gloss.
“With this easy 4-step routine, you can ensure you have fresh, glowing skin in no time.”

Try this skincare hack to ring in 2025 with radiant skin for your New Year's party!

item.title: Winter Depression: Seasonal Affective Disorder and how to deal with it - DNA India
item.description:
Winter Depression: Seasonal Affective Disorder and how to deal with it

Date: Dec 16, 2024 Source: DNA

Winter Depression, also known as Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD), can significantly affect mental health, particularly among the youth, during the winter months. The disorder is often associated with shorter days and reduced sunlight exposure.

  • Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD) primarily affects individuals in winter and autumn.
  • It impacts mood, feelings, and energy levels, particularly among youth.
  • Key contributing factors include shorter daylight hours and decreased physical activity in winter.
  • Experts indicate that less sunlight can worsen mental health issues like depression and anxiety.
  • Engaging in outdoor activities to soak up sunlight can help prevent winter depression.
  • Increasing physical activity can be beneficial in managing SAD.
  • Meditation may also assist in calming the mind and combating depressive symptoms.
  • Maintaining a healthy routine and being socially active can promote better mental health during winter.
“This information is not DNA's opinion but obtained from media reports.”

Taking proactive steps can help mitigate the effects of winter depression, ensuring mental well-being during the colder months.

item.title: Ditch these beliefs for a better health - The Indian Express
item.description:
Ditch These Beliefs for Better Health

Publication Date: December 2024 Source: The Indian Express

This article discusses common misconceptions regarding health and fitness, highlighting the importance of evidence-based practices for better well-being.

  • Fitness and nutrition are relatively modern subjects, lacking the historical depth of disciplines like physics.
  • Low-calorie diets might offer immediate results but negatively affect metabolism and productivity.
  • Excessive cardio without strength training can lead to muscle loss and decreased fitness.
  • Energy drinks often lead to overconsumption of sugar and are unnecessary for most individuals.
  • Mobility exercises are essential for preventing stiffness and maintaining flexibility.
  • Personalized fitness and nutrition plans are more effective than generalized advice.
“Most people don't need energy drinks, as they can cause overindulgence in sugar, which can lower insulin levels.”

In conclusion, adopting evidence-based health practices and personalized approaches can significantly improve overall wellness.

item.title: Study Says Flu Virus Remains In Refrigerated Raw Milk For Up To 5 Days - NDTV Food
item.description:
Flu Virus Found to Survive in Refrigerated Raw Milk for Up to 5 Days

Publication Date: August 29, 2024
Source: NDTV

A recent study from Stanford University reveals that the influenza virus can remain infectious in refrigerated raw milk for up to five days, raising concerns amid outbreaks of bird flu.

  • The flu virus H1N1 PR8 can survive in raw milk at refrigeration temperatures.
  • More than 14 million Americans consume raw milk annually, which is marketed as a healthier alternative to pasteurized milk.
  • The FDA has linked raw milk to over 200 illness outbreaks, highlighting significant health risks.
  • Flu virus RNA can remain detectable in raw milk for at least 57 days, posing challenges for food safety assessments.
  • Monitoring systems need improvement as bird flu spreads among livestock.
“This work highlights the potential risk of avian influenza transmission through consumption of raw milk and the importance of milk pasteurization.” - Alexandria Boehm, Senior Author

The findings of this research emphasize significant health risks associated with raw milk consumption, particularly in light of ongoing bird flu infections in cattle.

item.title: Bolster efforts to end TB in WHO South-East Asia Region - World Health Organization
item.description:
Bolster efforts to end TB in WHO South-East Asia Region

Publication Date: Not specified Source: WHO South-East Asia Regional Office

The World Health Organization has urged member countries in the South-East Asia Region to enhance efforts to eliminate tuberculosis (TB) by emphasizing multi-sectoral strategies at the political level. This includes focusing on socio-economic factors affecting TB and leveraging new technologies.

  • In 2023, a record 3.8 million people started TB treatment in the region.
  • The death toll from TB decreased to 583,000 in 2023, down from a peak of 763,000 in 2021.
  • The region is still responsible for 45% of the global TB burden with over 5 million new cases in 2023.
  • Efforts must be made to ensure equitable access to TB treatment and preventive services, especially for vulnerable populations.
“It is time to push the pedal on the momentum built collectively by the Member countries of the Region in efforts towards ending TB.” - Saima Wazed, Regional Director, WHO South-East Asia Region

In conclusion, there is an urgent need for increased collaboration and funding to address the TB crisis in South-East Asia, emphasizing that no one should be left behind in the global effort to eradicate this disease.

item.title: 5 anti-inflammatory foods for a healthier lifestyle - Mint
item.description:
5 Anti-Inflammatory Foods for a Healthier Lifestyle

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Healthline

Chronic inflammation can contribute to various diseases, making it essential to include anti-inflammatory foods in your diet to promote better health.

  • Incorporating these foods can help reduce inflammation.
  • Understanding the role of inflammation in the body is crucial.

Although inflammation plays a crucial role in defending the body against infection and injury, chronic inflammation can lead to the development of diseases.

Including specific foods in your diet can be a proactive way to manage inflammation and improve overall health.
